cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
Thomas Cromwell was executed for treason after being blamed for Henry VIII?s failed marriage to whom?
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process:
To answer the question, we need to identify the marriage that led to Thomas Cromwell's execution for treason. Thomas Cromwell was a key advisor to King Henry VIII and played a significant role in the king's efforts to annul his marriage to Catherine of Aragon. This annulment was crucial for Henry VIII because he wanted to marry Anne Boleyn, with whom he was infatuated. The failure of this marriage and the subsequent political and religious turmoil it caused ultimately led to Cromwell's downfall. He was blamed for the failure of the marriage to Anne Boleyn, which resulted in her execution and Cromwell's own execution for treason.

Answer:
Anne Boleyn

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
Thomas Cromwell was executed for treason after being blamed for Henry VIII?s failed marriage to whom?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The French ambassador, Marillac was to write to Montmorency on 3 March 1541 that Henry VIII had reproached his ministers for Cromwell\'s death, "saying that, upon light pretexts, by false accusations, they made him put to death the most faithful servant he ever had." It appears that Henry VIII no longer considered Thomas Cromwell to have been guilty of the charges against him, that he had been misled by his councillors and now regretted the loss of an able minister.\n', 'BULLET::::- 28 July – Thomas Cromwell is executed on order from the king on charges of treason in public on Tower Hill, London. Henry marries his fifth wife, Catherine Howard, on the same day at Oatlands Palace.\n', 'BULLET::::- 1540 – Thomas Cromwell is executed at the order of Henry VIII of England on charges of treason. Henry marries his fifth wife, Catherine Howard, on the same day.\n', 'For this he was thrown into the Beauchamp Tower in the Tower of London, and after a year\'s liberation again imprisoned, in December, 1533, on the charges of disseminating the prophecies of the Maid of Kent, encouraging the queen "obstinately to persist in her wilful opinion against the same divorce and separation", and maintaining her right to the title of queen. He was kept in close confinement until his execution at Smithfield, two days after the execution of Thomas Cromwell. There is still to be seen on the wall of his prison in the Tower of London a rebus consisting of the symbol of a bell with an A upon it and the name Thomas above, which he carved during his confinement. There is extant a very pious Latin letter written by him to a fellow-martyr, and another to Cromwell, begging for some slight mitigation of his "close prison"; "license to go to church and say Mass here within the Tower and for to lie in some house upon the Green". It is signed "by your daily bedeman, Thomas Abell, priest".\n', "Thomas Cromwell was at the height of his ascendancy, however his political enemies were gaining ground and his time in power would soon come to an end. He was arrested at a council meeting at 3.00 p.m. on the afternoon of 10 June 1540, accused of treason and heresy, taken to the Tower and his possessions seized. He was condemned without a trial and his sentence was later confirmed by an act of attainder. There are no surviving records of Gregory and Elizabeth's whereabouts at this time.\n", 'On 28 June 1540 Cromwell, Henry\'s longtime advisor and loyal servant, was executed. Different reasons were advanced: that Cromwell would not enforce the Act of Six Articles; that he had supported Robert Barnes, Hugh Latimer and other heretics; and that he was responsible for Henry\'s marriage to Anne of Cleves, his fourth wife. Many other arrests under the Act followed. On 30 July, the reformers Barnes, William Jerome and Thomas Gerrard were burned at the stake. In a display of religious impartiality, Thomas Abell, Richard Featherstone and Edward Powell—all Roman Catholics—were hanged and quartered while the Protestants burned. European observers were shocked and bewildered. French diplomat Charles de Marillac wrote that Henry\'s religious policy was a "climax of evils" and that:\n', 'BULLET::::- Thomas Cromwell: former Principle Secretary to Henry VIII, who was arrested at a Privy Council meeting in 1540, and charged with treason, executed on the grounds of an Attainder\n', 'BULLET::::- 28 July: Thomas Cromwell is executed on order from the king on charges of treason in public on Tower Hill.\n', 'BULLET::::- July 28 – One of the most important political figures of the reign of Henry VIII of England, Thomas Cromwell, is executed on order from the king, on charges of treason. Henry marries his fifth wife, Catherine Howard, on the same day.\n', "Gregory and Elizabeth were not implicated, although, unfortunately, it would be many months before their desperate situation was to be resolved. Their lives were still in danger from an increasingly paranoid king. It is unknown if Gregory and his family were present at Thomas Cromwell's execution or if permission was given by the king to bury his beloved father with dignity, as Sir Thomas More's family had, under the floor in the Chapel of St. Peter ad Vincula in the Tower.\n"]

To answer the question regarding Thomas Cromwell's execution and the failed marriage to Henry VIII's fourth wife, Anne of Cleves, we can extract and analyze relevant content from the provided passages. 

### Extracted Content:

1. **Cromwell's Role and Execution**:
   - "Thomas Cromwell was at the height of his ascendancy... He was arrested at a council meeting... accused of treason and heresy, taken to the Tower and his possessions seized."
   - "On 28 June 1540 Cromwell... executed. Different reasons were advanced: that Cromwell would not enforce the Act of Six Articles; that he had supported Robert Barnes, Hugh Latimer and other heretics; and that he was responsible for Henry's marriage to Anne of Cleves, his fourth wife."

2. **Context of the Marriage to Anne of Cleves**:
   - "Henry marries his fifth wife, Catherine Howard, on the same day [of Cromwell's execution]."
   - Cromwell's involvement in the marriage to Anne of Cleves was a significant factor in his downfall, as it was seen as a political miscalculation that did not yield the expected alliance with Germany.

3. **Political Climate**:
   - "Cromwell's political enemies were gaining ground and his time in power would soon come to an end."
   - "He was condemned without a trial and his sentence was later confirmed by an act of attainder."

4. **Henry VIII's Regret**:
   - "Henry VIII had reproached his ministers for Cromwell's death... saying that, upon light pretexts, by false accusations, they made him put to death the most faithful servant he ever had."

### Analysis of the Role of Extracted Content:

1. **Cromwell's Role and Execution**:
   - Understanding Cromwell's position as a key advisor to Henry VIII helps contextualize why his execution was significant. His arrest and execution were politically motivated, reflecting the volatile nature of Tudor politics and the dangers of court intrigue.

2. **Context of the Marriage to Anne of Cleves**:
   - The marriage to Anne of Cleves was intended to strengthen alliances but was ultimately viewed as a failure, leading to Cromwell being blamed for this misstep. This highlights the intersection of personal relationships and political strategy during Henry VIII's reign.

3. **Political Climate**:
   - The mention of Cromwell's political enemies and the act of attainder illustrates the precariousness of power during this period. Cromwell's downfall was not just due to his actions but also the shifting allegiances and rivalries within the court.

4. **Henry VIII's Regret**:
   - This content reveals a later reflection by Henry VIII, indicating that the king may have recognized the injustice of Cromwell's execution. It adds a layer of complexity to the narrative, suggesting that Cromwell's execution was not only a political maneuver but also a tragic consequence of the king's reliance on his council.

### Conclusion:
The extracted content provides a deeper understanding of the political dynamics surrounding Thomas Cromwell's execution, particularly in relation to his role in Henry VIII's marriage to Anne of Cleves. It highlights the interplay of personal and political factors in Tudor England, illustrating how Cromwell's downfall was tied to both his political enemies and the king's changing sentiments. This background knowledge is crucial for comprehending the complexities of Cromwell's execution and its implications for the Tudor court.

To accurately answer the question regarding Thomas Cromwell's execution for treason and the failed marriage he was blamed for, we need to clarify the historical context and the specific marriage involved.

1. **Cromwell's Role**: Thomas Cromwell was a prominent advisor to King Henry VIII and played a significant role in the king's marital affairs, particularly in the annulment of Henry's first marriage to Catherine of Aragon and the subsequent marriage to Anne Boleyn. However, the marriage that directly led to his execution was to Anne of Cleves, Henry's fourth wife.

2. **Marriage to Anne of Cleves**: Cromwell arranged the marriage to Anne of Cleves in 1540, believing it would strengthen political alliances with Germany. However, the marriage was a disaster; Henry found Anne unattractive and sought an annulment shortly after the marriage was consummated. This failure was seen as a significant political blunder, and Cromwell was blamed for it.

3. **Political Consequences**: Following the failed marriage, Cromwell's political enemies capitalized on the situation. He was arrested on charges of treason and heresy, and his execution was ordered without a fair trial, reflecting the cutthroat nature of Tudor politics. His downfall illustrates the precariousness of power and the rapid shifts in loyalty and favor at court.

4. **Henry VIII's Regret**: After Cromwell's execution, Henry VIII reportedly expressed regret over the decision, indicating that he had been misled by his councilors and recognized Cromwell as a loyal servant. This regret underscores the complexity of Cromwell's position and the political machinations that led to his demise.

### Conclusion:
The marriage to Anne of Cleves was a pivotal moment in Cromwell's career, leading to his execution for treason. Understanding the political dynamics, Cromwell's role in the marriage, and the subsequent fallout provides a clearer picture of why he was blamed and ultimately executed.

### Answer:
Anne of Cleves

1. **Cromwell's Execution**: Thomas Cromwell was executed on July 28, 1540, on charges of treason. His execution was ordered by King Henry VIII, and it occurred publicly at Tower Hill, London.

2. **Marriage to Anne of Cleves**: Cromwell was blamed for Henry VIII's failed marriage to Anne of Cleves, who was Henry's fourth wife. This marriage was politically motivated but turned out to be unsuccessful, leading to its annulment shortly after the wedding.

3. **Political Context**: Cromwell was a significant political figure and advisor to Henry VIII. His downfall was attributed to various factors, including his association with reformist figures and his failure to enforce certain religious policies, which alienated him from powerful factions at court.

4. **Regret from Henry VIII**: After Cromwell's execution, there were indications that Henry VIII regretted the decision, as he later expressed that Cromwell was one of his most faithful servants and had been misled by his councillors regarding the charges against him.

- **Cromwell's Influence**: Recognizing Cromwell's influence on Henry VIII's policies and decisions helps clarify why his failure to secure a successful marriage with Anne of Cleves was seen as a betrayal, leading to accusations of treason.

- **Regret and Reflection**: The later regret expressed by Henry VIII adds a layer of complexity to the narrative, suggesting that Cromwell's execution was not merely a political maneuver but also a reflection of the king's volatile nature and the precariousness of court politics.

Thomas Cromwell was executed for treason largely due to his association with Henry VIII's failed marriage to Anne of Cleves. His execution on July 28, 1540, was a result of political machinations and shifting allegiances within the court, as well as his failure to navigate the complex religious landscape of the time. Despite his significant contributions to the king's administration, Cromwell became a scapegoat for the failures of the marriage, leading to his downfall. The subsequent regret expressed by Henry VIII highlights the often arbitrary nature of power and the consequences of political rivalries in Tudor England. Understanding these dynamics deepens our comprehension of the historical significance of Cromwell's life and death, as well as the broader implications for the Tudor monarchy.

1. **Execution Date and Charges**: Thomas Cromwell was executed on July 28, 1540, on charges of treason. He was accused of various offenses, including not enforcing the Act of Six Articles and being responsible for Henry VIII's marriage to Anne of Cleves, his fourth wife.

2. **Political Context**: Cromwell was a significant political figure and advisor to Henry VIII. His execution came at a time when he was facing increasing opposition from political enemies, which contributed to his downfall.

3. **Henry VIII's Regret**: After Cromwell's execution, Henry VIII reportedly expressed regret, indicating that he had been misled by his councillors and no longer considered Cromwell guilty of the charges against him.

4. **Marriage to Catherine Howard**: On the same day as Cromwell's execution, Henry VIII married Catherine Howard, which suggests a shift in the king's political alliances and personal relationships that may have influenced Cromwell's fate.

5. **Historical Reactions**: The execution of Cromwell and the subsequent actions taken against other reformers and Catholics were viewed with shock and bewilderment by European observers, indicating the broader implications of Cromwell's execution on the political and religious landscape of the time.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:
1. **Understanding Causality**: The relationship between Cromwell's execution and the political dynamics of the time illustrates how individual actions (Cromwell's policies and alliances) can lead to significant consequences (his execution and the king's subsequent marriage). This helps the model understand how specific events can be causally linked to broader historical outcomes.

2. **Inference from Regret**: Henry VIII's regret after Cromwell's execution suggests a complex interplay of loyalty, betrayal, and political maneuvering. The model can learn to infer that decisions made under pressure or misinformation can lead to regrettable outcomes, enhancing its ability to analyze human behavior and decision-making processes.

3. **Contextual Relationships**: The simultaneous occurrence of Cromwell's execution and Henry's marriage to Catherine Howard highlights the importance of context in understanding events. The model can improve its ability to recognize that events do not happen in isolation but are often interconnected, requiring a nuanced understanding of the surrounding circumstances.

4. **Reactions and Consequences**: The reactions of European observers to Cromwell's execution can inform the model about the societal and political ramifications of individual actions. This understanding can enhance the model's ability to predict how similar events might be perceived in different contexts, improving its inferential reasoning.

By consolidating these points, the model can better grasp the complexities of historical events, the motivations behind actions, and the consequences that follow, ultimately improving its causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities.

question:
Thomas Cromwell was executed for treason after being blamed for Henry VIII?s failed marriage to whom?
answer:
Reasoning process:
To answer the question, we need to identify the marriage that led to Thomas Cromwell's execution for treason. Thomas Cromwell was a key advisor to King Henry VIII and played a significant role in the king's efforts to annul his marriage to Catherine of Aragon. This annulment was crucial for Henry VIII because he wanted to marry Anne Boleyn, with whom he was infatuated. The failure of this marriage and the subsequent political and religious turmoil it caused ultimately led to Cromwell's downfall. He was blamed for the failure of the marriage to Anne Boleyn, which resulted in her execution and Cromwell's own execution for treason.

Answer:
Anne Boleyn

To answer the question about whom Thomas Cromwell was blamed for regarding Henry VIII's failed marriage, we must clarify the historical context and the specific marriage in question. 

1. **Cromwell's Role**: Thomas Cromwell was a key advisor to Henry VIII and played a significant role in the king's marital decisions. He was instrumental in facilitating Henry's marriage to Anne of Cleves, which ultimately turned out to be politically and personally disastrous for the king.

2. **Failed Marriage**: The marriage to Anne of Cleves was arranged to form an alliance with Protestant Germany. However, Henry found Anne unattractive and the marriage was never consummated. This failure led to significant political fallout, and Cromwell was blamed for the arrangement.

3. **Execution Context**: Cromwell was executed on July 28, 1540, on charges of treason. His execution occurred shortly after the annulment of his marriage to Anne of Cleves, which was a direct consequence of the king's dissatisfaction. This indicates that Cromwell's downfall was closely tied to the failure of this specific marriage.

4. **Political Enemies**: Cromwell had many political enemies who capitalized on the failure of the marriage to undermine him. His execution was not only a result of the failed marriage but also a culmination of rising opposition against him in the court.

5. **Henry VIII's Regret**: After Cromwell's execution, Henry VIII expressed regret, suggesting that he had been misled by his advisors about Cromwell's loyalty and capabilities. This indicates that the political machinations surrounding Cromwell's downfall were complex and involved multiple layers of betrayal and misjudgment.

6. **Historical Implications**: The execution of Cromwell and the subsequent marriage to Catherine Howard on the same day highlight the rapid shifts in political alliances and the volatile nature of court politics during Henry VIII's reign.

### Enhanced Reasoning:
By synthesizing the above points, we can conclude that Thomas Cromwell was primarily blamed for the failed marriage to **Anne of Cleves**. His execution was a direct consequence of this failure, compounded by political rivalries and the king's shifting allegiances. The model can learn that individual actions, such as Cromwell's role in the marriage, can have significant and far-reaching consequences, illustrating the interconnectedness of political decisions and personal relationships in historical contexts.

### Answer:
Anne of Cleves

To answer the following question:
Thomas Cromwell was executed for treason after being blamed for Henry VIII?s failed marriage to whom?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The French ambassador, Marillac was to write to Montmorency on 3 March 1541 that Henry VIII had reproached his ministers for Cromwell\'s death, "saying that, upon light pretexts, by false accusations, they made him put to death the most faithful servant he ever had." It appears that Henry VIII no longer considered Thomas Cromwell to have been guilty of the charges against him, that he had been misled by his councillors and now regretted the loss of an able minister.\n', 'BULLET::::- 28 July – Thomas Cromwell is executed on order from the king on charges of treason in public on Tower Hill, London. Henry marries his fifth wife, Catherine Howard, on the same day at Oatlands Palace.\n', 'BULLET::::- 1540 – Thomas Cromwell is executed at the order of Henry VIII of England on charges of treason. Henry marries his fifth wife, Catherine Howard, on the same day.\n', 'For this he was thrown into the Beauchamp Tower in the Tower of London, and after a year\'s liberation again imprisoned, in December, 1533, on the charges of disseminating the prophecies of the Maid of Kent, encouraging the queen "obstinately to persist in her wilful opinion against the same divorce and separation", and maintaining her right to the title of queen. He was kept in close confinement until his execution at Smithfield, two days after the execution of Thomas Cromwell. There is still to be seen on the wall of his prison in the Tower of London a rebus consisting of the symbol of a bell with an A upon it and the name Thomas above, which he carved during his confinement. There is extant a very pious Latin letter written by him to a fellow-martyr, and another to Cromwell, begging for some slight mitigation of his "close prison"; "license to go to church and say Mass here within the Tower and for to lie in some house upon the Green". It is signed "by your daily bedeman, Thomas Abell, priest".\n', "Thomas Cromwell was at the height of his ascendancy, however his political enemies were gaining ground and his time in power would soon come to an end. He was arrested at a council meeting at 3.00 p.m. on the afternoon of 10 June 1540, accused of treason and heresy, taken to the Tower and his possessions seized. He was condemned without a trial and his sentence was later confirmed by an act of attainder. There are no surviving records of Gregory and Elizabeth's whereabouts at this time.\n", 'On 28 June 1540 Cromwell, Henry\'s longtime advisor and loyal servant, was executed. Different reasons were advanced: that Cromwell would not enforce the Act of Six Articles; that he had supported Robert Barnes, Hugh Latimer and other heretics; and that he was responsible for Henry\'s marriage to Anne of Cleves, his fourth wife. Many other arrests under the Act followed. On 30 July, the reformers Barnes, William Jerome and Thomas Gerrard were burned at the stake. In a display of religious impartiality, Thomas Abell, Richard Featherstone and Edward Powell—all Roman Catholics—were hanged and quartered while the Protestants burned. European observers were shocked and bewildered. French diplomat Charles de Marillac wrote that Henry\'s religious policy was a "climax of evils" and that:\n', 'BULLET::::- Thomas Cromwell: former Principle Secretary to Henry VIII, who was arrested at a Privy Council meeting in 1540, and charged with treason, executed on the grounds of an Attainder\n', 'BULLET::::- 28 July: Thomas Cromwell is executed on order from the king on charges of treason in public on Tower Hill.\n', 'BULLET::::- July 28 – One of the most important political figures of the reign of Henry VIII of England, Thomas Cromwell, is executed on order from the king, on charges of treason. Henry marries his fifth wife, Catherine Howard, on the same day.\n', "Gregory and Elizabeth were not implicated, although, unfortunately, it would be many months before their desperate situation was to be resolved. Their lives were still in danger from an increasingly paranoid king. It is unknown if Gregory and his family were present at Thomas Cromwell's execution or if permission was given by the king to bury his beloved father with dignity, as Sir Thomas More's family had, under the floor in the Chapel of St. Peter ad Vincula in the Tower.\n"]

     - His failure to enforce the **Act of Six Articles**.
     - His support for **heretics** like Robert Barnes and Hugh Latimer.

4. **Condemnation Without Trial**:

This highlights the political nature of his execution and the lack of due process, which could be an important aspect to include in discussions about the legal and political practices of the time.

5. **Political Enemies**:
   - The mention of Cromwell's political enemies gaining ground suggests that his execution was also a result of internal court politics, which could provide a broader context for understanding the motivations behind his downfall.

This would help alleviate potential model illusions regarding the simplicity of Cromwell's charges and the circumstances of his execution.

Answer:

**Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:**

To accurately answer the question regarding Thomas Cromwell's execution for treason, we need to clarify the context surrounding his downfall and the specific marriage he was blamed for. 

1. **Cromwell's Role**: Thomas Cromwell was a key advisor to King Henry VIII and played a significant role in the king's marital affairs, particularly in the annulment of Henry's marriage to Catherine of Aragon, which allowed Henry to marry Anne Boleyn. However, the question specifically asks about the marriage for which Cromwell was blamed at the time of his execution.

2. **Failed Marriage**: The passages indicate that Cromwell was blamed for the failure of Henry's marriage to **Anne of Cleves**, Henry's fourth wife. This marriage was politically motivated but ended in failure, leading to Henry's dissatisfaction and subsequent annulment. Cromwell's association with this marriage was a significant factor in the charges against him.

3. **Execution Context**: Cromwell was executed on **28 July 1540**, on charges of treason, coinciding with Henry VIII's marriage to his fifth wife, **Catherine Howard**. This timing suggests a dramatic shift in court politics and highlights Cromwell's fall from favor.

4. **Multiple Charges**: The passages reveal that Cromwell faced various accusations, including his failure to enforce the **Act of Six Articles** and his support for Protestant reformers, which contributed to the perception of him as a political liability. This multifaceted blame underscores the complexity of his situation and the interplay of religious and political factors in his execution.

5. **Henry VIII's Regret**: After Cromwell's execution, Henry VIII reportedly expressed regret, indicating that he had been misled by his advisors and no longer believed Cromwell was guilty of the charges. This reflects the volatile nature of court politics and the potential for historical reinterpretation of Cromwell's legacy.

By integrating these insights, we can clarify that while Cromwell was involved in the annulment of Henry's marriage to Catherine of Aragon and the marriage to Anne Boleyn, he was specifically blamed for the failure of the marriage to **Anne of Cleves**, which ultimately contributed to his execution.

**Answer**: Anne of Cleves

question_info.question: Thomas Cromwell was executed for treason after being blamed for Henry VIII?s failed marriage to whom?
passages:
The French ambassador, Marillac was to write to Montmorency on 3 March 1541 that Henry VIII had reproached his ministers for Cromwell's death, "saying that, upon light pretexts, by false accusations, they made him put to death the most faithful servant he ever had." It appears that Henry VIII no longer considered Thomas Cromwell to have been guilty of the charges against him, that he had been misled by his councillors and now regretted the loss of an able minister.
BULLET::::- 28 July – Thomas Cromwell is executed on order from the king on charges of treason in public on Tower Hill, London. Henry marries his fifth wife, Catherine Howard, on the same day at Oatlands Palace.
BULLET::::- 1540 – Thomas Cromwell is executed at the order of Henry VIII of England on charges of treason. Henry marries his fifth wife, Catherine Howard, on the same day.
For this he was thrown into the Beauchamp Tower in the Tower of London, and after a year's liberation again imprisoned, in December, 1533, on the charges of disseminating the prophecies of the Maid of Kent, encouraging the queen "obstinately to persist in her wilful opinion against the same divorce and separation", and maintaining her right to the title of queen. He was kept in close confinement until his execution at Smithfield, two days after the execution of Thomas Cromwell. There is still to be seen on the wall of his prison in the Tower of London a rebus consisting of the symbol of a bell with an A upon it and the name Thomas above, which he carved during his confinement. There is extant a very pious Latin letter written by him to a fellow-martyr, and another to Cromwell, begging for some slight mitigation of his "close prison"; "license to go to church and say Mass here within the Tower and for to lie in some house upon the Green". It is signed "by your daily bedeman, Thomas Abell, priest".
Thomas Cromwell was at the height of his ascendancy, however his political enemies were gaining ground and his time in power would soon come to an end. He was arrested at a council meeting at 3.00 p.m. on the afternoon of 10 June 1540, accused of treason and heresy, taken to the Tower and his possessions seized. He was condemned without a trial and his sentence was later confirmed by an act of attainder. There are no surviving records of Gregory and Elizabeth's whereabouts at this time.
On 28 June 1540 Cromwell, Henry's longtime advisor and loyal servant, was executed. Different reasons were advanced: that Cromwell would not enforce the Act of Six Articles; that he had supported Robert Barnes, Hugh Latimer and other heretics; and that he was responsible for Henry's marriage to Anne of Cleves, his fourth wife. Many other arrests under the Act followed. On 30 July, the reformers Barnes, William Jerome and Thomas Gerrard were burned at the stake. In a display of religious impartiality, Thomas Abell, Richard Featherstone and Edward Powell—all Roman Catholics—were hanged and quartered while the Protestants burned. European observers were shocked and bewildered. French diplomat Charles de Marillac wrote that Henry's religious policy was a "climax of evils" and that:
BULLET::::- Thomas Cromwell: former Principle Secretary to Henry VIII, who was arrested at a Privy Council meeting in 1540, and charged with treason, executed on the grounds of an Attainder
BULLET::::- 28 July: Thomas Cromwell is executed on order from the king on charges of treason in public on Tower Hill.
BULLET::::- July 28 – One of the most important political figures of the reign of Henry VIII of England, Thomas Cromwell, is executed on order from the king, on charges of treason. Henry marries his fifth wife, Catherine Howard, on the same day.
Gregory and Elizabeth were not implicated, although, unfortunately, it would be many months before their desperate situation was to be resolved. Their lives were still in danger from an increasingly paranoid king. It is unknown if Gregory and his family were present at Thomas Cromwell's execution or if permission was given by the king to bury his beloved father with dignity, as Sir Thomas More's family had, under the floor in the Chapel of St. Peter ad Vincula in the Tower.
